TEXT: CARDINAL . ORG The applicant is a NORP national , resident in GPE , and was at the time of the events which gave rise to her complaints under the Convention married to X , who was not NORP . They divorced on DATE . They are both infected with the human immunodeficiency virus ( HIV ) .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE ORG ( raastuvanoikeus , rådstuvurätten ) convicted PERSON and sentenced him to a suspended term of imprisonment for rape on NORP on DATE . ORG held the trial in camera and ordered that the documents submitted in the case remain confidential for a certain period .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE X was informed of the results of a blood test performed on DATE , indicating that he was HIV - positive .

CARDINAL . ORG In DATE , following a complaint of a sexual offence lodged by PERSON , the police opened an investigation into attempted manslaughter , suspecting X of having deliberately subjected PERSON to a risk of infection with HIV on DATE .

According to the facts as established by the ORG , during a police interview on DATE CARDINAL M. identified X as the perpetrator and the police informed her that X ’s spouse , the applicant , was HIV - positive . On DATE , the police advised PERSON that X was also infected .

At the hearing before ORG disputed the Commission ’s finding that the police had informed PERSON that the applicant was an HIV carrier . The ORG replied that the finding had been based on corroborative evidence in the police investigation record and the minutes of the ensuing proceedings before ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . M. ’s boyfriend PERSON met the applicant in DATE and asked her whether her husband was an HIV carrier . On DATE PERSON telephoned her and cited passages from confidential court documents relating to the trial mentioned in paragraph CARDINAL above .
On DATE T. was interviewed by the police as to the content of this conversation .

CARDINAL , of the Code of Judicial Procedure ( oikeudenkäymiskaari , rättegångsbalk ) ) .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the public prosecutor charged X with sexual assault on M. On DATE PERSON brought a charge against X of attempted manslaughter .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the police interviewed the applicant but she again refused to give evidence against her spouse . She feared that the documents in the case , including any statement she made , would not remain confidential .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE NORP lodged a complaint with the police against X for rape committed on DATE . The police officer who recorded the complaint added to the record a statement that the applicant had already been found to be HIV - positive in DATE .
The Government submitted at the ORG ’s hearing that it was NORP who had told this to the police .

On DATE and DATE and DATE , the public prosecutor read out in court charges against X of attempted manslaughter in respect of offences committed against M. on DATE , against P. on DATE and against P .- L. on DATE and DATE . Such charges were also brought by P .- L. on DATE and by NORP on DATE in relation to offences committed respectively on DATE and DATE .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , at ORG first hearing , held in public , X refused to reply to a question put by PERSON ’s counsel as to whether the applicant was also an HIV carrier .

At a further hearing on DATE , ORG decided at the GPE request that the case should be heard in camera . PERSON confirmed that she had been informed by the police that the applicant was HIV - positive and T. gave evidence on the content of his telephone conversation with the applicant on DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE and with X ’s consent , PERSON , senior doctor at the hospital where PERSON and the applicant had been treated , transmitted copies of X ’s medical records to the public prosecutor . These had been edited so as to omit all references to the applicant .
CARDINAL . ORG summoned the applicant to appear before it as a witness on DATE , but she again relied on her right not to give evidence in a case concerning her husband .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE CARDINAL PERSON ’s counsel informed the public prosecutor that the copies of ORG medical records appeared to be incomplete . That same day the public prosecutor asked the police to obtain statements from senior doctor PERSON and any other doctors who had been treating GPE , whether as experts or ordinary witnesses , in order to obtain information from them on when X had become aware of his HIV infection .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , despite his objections , ORG ordered senior doctor PERSON to give evidence . He disclosed to the court medical data concerning the applicant which had been omitted from the copies of X ’s medical records referred to in paragraph CARDINAL above .
ORG , by way of an interim measure , ordered that the court file , including the transcripts of senior doctor PERSON ’s evidence , be kept confidential .

CARDINAL . ORG At the hearings of ORG on DATE and DATE , PERSON refused to answer a question put by counsel for the complainants ( PERSON , P .- L. , PERSON and NORP ) as to whether the applicant was HIV - positive . On DATE , counsel asked him when he had become aware that she was infected . However , X again refused to answer .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE senior doctor PERSON complained to the parliamentary ombudsman ( eduskunnan oikeusasiamies , riksdagens justitieombudsman ) about the court decision ordering him to give evidence . In an opinion of CARDINAL DATE the parliamentary ombudsman expressed the view that the domestic law had not been violated and that ORG had properly balanced the public interest in investigating crime against the applicant ’s interests in protecting the confidentiality of the information in question .

CARDINAL . ORG At a court hearing on DATE , PERSON , who had also treated the applicant , was , despite his objections , required to give evidence as a witness for the prosecution and to disclose information about the applicant . He did so .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the police interviewed PERSON as an expert . He provided them with general information on HIV infection and contamination .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the public prosecutor requested the police to interview the applicant ’s doctors as witnesses in the investigation into the charges against X of attempted manslaughter ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . However , since all the doctors concerned refused , the matter had to be referred to ORG .

CARDINAL . ORG Despite his renewed objections , senior doctor PERSON was again heard as a prosecution witness at ORG hearing of DATE . He once again disclosed information about the applicant . Before giving evidence he read out a letter dated DATE which the applicant had sent him . It stated :

" ... The case concerns criminal charges against my husband which are considered to outweigh a doctor ’s obligation and right to respect secrecy . It seems to me that you have been called to appear as a witness because I myself have invoked my right ... to refuse to give evidence . In your capacity as a doctor you are therefore likely to be asked questions which I , as X ’s spouse , have the right to refuse to reveal . The information which you have emanates from me and has been obtained by you because it has been my understanding that it would remain confidential ... [ N]or could I have imagined that [ such ] information could be used for the purpose of criminal proceedings in which my husband is facing charges .
As I see it , the hearing of you as a witness is merely aimed at circumventing my lawful right to refuse to give evidence against my husband ...

... I therefore request you to refer to these points , when you are being asked to give evidence in matters which concern only me . It is my opinion that you should not be obliged to give evidence in those matters and that the charges should be dealt with in such a way that I am not in any way forced to take part in the establishment of the [ facts ] . [ I ] am under no obligation to do so ... "

CARDINAL . ORG In the course of CARDINAL hearings on DATE , DATE and CARDINAL DATE , ORG heard evidence from the applicant ’s psychiatrist , PERSON , and a number of medical doctors who had treated her , namely Drs V. , S .- H. , PERSON , T. , NORP and apparently also Dr PERSON It also heard PERSON , who had interviewed Z for research purposes . The prosecution had called them as witnesses and the court had ordered them to give evidence , although they had objected to doing so .
At the hearing on DATE , Dr NORP confirmed that a blood test performed in DATE had shown that the applicant was HIV - positive .

At the hearing on DATE the applicant agreed to give evidence since the matters which related to her had already been dealt with by ORG in other ways . In her evidence she stated amongst other things that she had not been infected with HIV by X.

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the police carried out a search at the hospital where the applicant and X had occasionally been treated . The police seized all the records concerning the applicant and appended copies of these to the record of the investigation concerning the charges against X of attempted manslaughter . These measures had been ordered by the prosecution . After photocopying the records the police returned them to the hospital .
The seized records comprised CARDINAL documents including the following statements :
DATE : [ The applicant was ] found to be HIV - positive at the beginning of the autumn of DATE . [ She ] guesses that she was contaminated at DATE ...
[ She ] is married to a [ foreign ] citizen , whom she thinks is [ HIV]-negative .
DATE : ... [ The applicant ’s husband ] completely denies that he might have an HIV infection ...
DATE : ... According to [ the applicant ] , [ her ] husband probably has an HIV infection too but [ he ] has not gone to be tested ...
DATE : ... [ The applicant ’s husband ] has not gone for HIV tests and is of the opinion that he is not a carrier of the virus ... "

CARDINAL . ORG The police also seized results from a large number of laboratory tests and examinations concerning matters other than the existence of HIV in the applicant ’s blood , including information about her previous illnesses , her mental state and a survey into her quality of life based on a self - assessment .
On DATE ORG decided to include the copies of the seized records in its case file . On DATE it heard Dr S.V. as an expert called by the prosecution .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE ORG , amongst other things , convicted X on CARDINAL counts of attempted manslaughter committed on DATE , CARDINAL DATE and DATE but dismissed the charge of attempted manslaughter for the offence committed on DATE and , as regards the latter , convicted him of rape instead . ORG sentenced him to terms of imprisonment totalling DATE .

ORG published the operative part of the judgment , an abridged version of its reasoning and an indication of the law which it had applied in the case . ORG ordered that the full reasoning and the documents in the case be kept confidential for DATE . Both the complainants as well as X had requested a longer period of confidentiality .
CARDINAL . ORG The complainants , X and the prosecution all appealed against ORG judgment to ORG ( hovioikeus , hovrätten ) .

CARDINAL . ORG At a hearing in camera before ORG on DATE , all the appellants requested that the duration of the confidentiality order be extended ; an extension to DATE was discussed . X ’s lawyer also informed the court about the applicant ’s wish that the order be extended .

CARDINAL . ORG In a judgment of DATE , a copy of which was made available to the press ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , ORG , inter alia , upheld the conviction of X on CARDINAL counts of attempted manslaughter and , in addition , convicted him on CARDINAL further such counts related to offences committed on DATE and DATE . It increased his total sentence to DATE , DATE and CARDINAL days’ imprisonment .
As regards the CARDINAL additional counts of attempted manslaughter , the judgment stated :

" ... According to [ X - mentioned by his first names and family name ] he found out that he was suffering from an HIV infection on DATE ... He denied having undergone any HIV examination since being tested in GPE in DATE .
According to [ X ] , the result of the HIV test was negative ...
[ He ] can not therefore be considered to have known with certainty that he was infected with HIV prior to receiving the results of the test on DATE .

[ X ] and [ the applicant - mentioned by her first names and family name ] got married on DATE . On DATE [ the applicant ] was found to be an HIV carrier . When she gave evidence before ORG , [ she ] said that she had informed X of this finding at DATE . In ORG , X said that the applicant had already informed him about her disease before he came to GPE in DATE . [ He ] also said that while they were both living in LOC [ the applicant ] had been suffering from some undefined disease . [ She ] had then also suspected that she might have become contaminated with HIV but her infection had only been discovered after [ she ] had returned to GPE .

On the basis of the above statements by the spouses ... it must be considered established that , given the status of [ X ’s ] wife as an HIV carrier , [ X ] had particular reason to suspect that the infection had been transmitted through their sexual intercourse .

According to [ Dr J.S. ] , a witness before ORG , [ X ] must , on the basis of the symptoms of his disease , be considered to have been infected with HIV DATE before the blood test performed in DATE ... According to [ Dr GPE ] , the disease with symptoms of fever which , according to [ the applicant ’s ] medical records , she is reported to have suffered from in DATE and which was treated as malaria is quite likely to have been a primary HIV infection . Regard being had to the fact that , when she contracted [ her ] disease with symptoms of fever at DATE or DATE , [ the applicant ] was staying in GPE , where she had also met [ X ] , ORG finds PERSON opinion concerning the primary HIV infection credible . Taking into account the moment when [ the applicant ] was found to be an HIV carrier , ORG finds it likely that she contracted the [ disease ] from [ X ] .

On these grounds ORG considers that [ X ] must have been aware of his HIV infection at the latest by DATE . The fact that [ he ] nevertheless chose not to undergo any HIV examinations other than those referred to above shows that his attitude towards the possibility that others might be contaminated [ with HIV ] was at best indifferent . Such an attitude must , as regards the question of intent , be considered in the same way as if the perpetrator had known with certainty that he had the disease . When assessing [ X ’s ] intent , his conduct must therefore be viewed in the same way on all the counts of attempted manslaughter with which he has been charged .

It has been shown in this case that , on the basis of current knowledge , an HIV infection is lethal . [ X ] has admitted that , before arriving in GPE , he had already become familiar with the nature of [ this ] disease and the ways in which it could spread . Having regard also to [ his ] statement that he had [ previously ] stayed in GPE , GPE and GPE , GPE being a country where the disease is particularly widespread , and the general knowledge that [ the disease ] is lethal , and [ noting ] that [ X ’s ] wife has also fallen ill [ with this disease ] , [ ORG ] finds it likely that [ X ] was familiar with the significant risk of contamination and the lethal effects of [ the disease ] .

According to [ senior doctor PERSON ] and [ Dr GPE ] , who were called as witnesses , the disease may spread through a single act of sexual intercourse ... X must thus have realised that his acts entailed , as a probable consequence , subjecting [ the complainants ] to a risk that they would be contaminated with HIV . Given that he has nevertheless acted in the manner established , his acts must be considered intentional . In this respect ORG has also taken into account that [ X ] did not inform the complainants of the possible risk of contamination .
... [ X ] must therefore be considered to have committed attempted manslaughter ... on DATE and DATE also ... "
ORG in addition upheld ORG decision that the case documents should remain confidential for DATE .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE ORG ( korkein oikeus , högsta domstolen ) refused to grant X leave to appeal .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the applicant applied to ORG for an order quashing ( poistaa , undanröja ) ORG judgment in so far as it permitted the information and material about her to become available to the public as from DATE . In her view , ORG failure to hear her submissions before deciding whether and for how long the relevant medical records should be kept confidential amounted to a procedural error . That part of its judgment had been prejudicial to her .

In the alternative , she applied for an order reversing ( purkaa , återbryta ) ORG judgment , on the grounds that it had manifestly been based on an incorrect application of the law and was incompatible with LAW ( article CARDINAL) in that it was neither " in accordance with the law " nor " necessary in a NORP society " .
In the event that ORG judgment be quashed or reversed , the applicant requested that the matter be referred back to ORG , so that she could make submissions .

CARDINAL . ORG On CARDINAL DATE the applicant requested ORG to make enquiries as to who had informed the police that she was HIV - positive ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . She withdrew her request DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s application for an order quashing or reversing ORG judgment . The first application had been lodged out of time and she did not have locus standi to make the second .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the large - circulation evening newspaper GPE reported GPE ’s trial , stating that he was infected with HIV and that it was not yet certain whether the applicant was also infected , as she had refused to give evidence .

CARDINAL . ORG judgment of DATE was reported by various newspapers , including PERSON which , after receiving it by fax from ORG , published an article on DATE . The article stated that the conviction had been based on the statement of " [ X ] ’s NORP wife " , while mentioning his name in full ; in addition , it referred to ORG finding that the applicant was HIV - positive .

CARDINAL . ORG Under LAW DATE and implementing decree ( tartuntatautilaki CARDINAL/CARDINAL ja -asetus CARDINAL/CARDINAL , lag CARDINAL/CARDINAL och förordning CARDINAL om smittsamma sjukdomar ) , a person who is suffering from a disease such as infection with HIV or who it is found might have contracted such a disease must , on request , inform his or her doctor of the likely source of contamination ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of the LAW and section CARDINAL of the decree ) .

CARDINAL . ORG Under the Patients’ LAW DATE ( laki potilaan asemasta ja oikeuksista , lag om patientens ställning och rättigheter DATE ) which entered into force on DATE , medical records must be kept confidential . Information may only be disclosed to a third party with the patient ’s written consent . It may nevertheless be disclosed to , among others , a court of law , another authority or an association which has been granted access thereto by law ( section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . ORG Under chapter DATE , Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) , of LAW , a doctor of medicine may not , without his or her patient ’s consent , give information as a witness which he or she has obtained in his or her professional capacity and which , because of its nature , should be kept confidential .

However , paragraph CARDINAL provides that a doctor may be ordered to give evidence as a witness in connection with a charge relating to an offence for which a sentence of DATE imprisonment is prescribed ( as is the case with regard to manslaughter and attempted manslaughter ) .

In such cases , section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of the Pre - trial LAW DATE ( esitutkintalaki , förundersökningslag CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) entitles doctors to give evidence even during the pre - trial investigation .
CARDINAL . ORG LAW ( CARDINAL ) of that LAW provides :

" If a witness manifestly has knowledge about a matter of importance to the clarification of [ a suspect ’s ] guilt and if he [ or she ] refuses to reveal this even though obliged to do so or , under section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) , entitled to do so , the court may , at the request of the chief investigating officer , require [ the witness ] to disclose his knowledge about the matter . In such cases all or part of the questioning of the witness may take place in court . "

A party to the pre - trial investigation and his counsel may attend the proceedings in which such a request by the chief investigating officer is considered and the actual hearing where the witness gives evidence ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) .
CARDINAL . ORG LAW , LAW CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) , of ORG DATE ( pakkokinolaki , tvångsmedelslagen CARDINAL ) provides :

" A document shall not be seized for evidential purposes if it may be presumed to contain information in regard to which a person referred to in DATE , Article CARDINAL , of the Code of Judicial Procedure is not allowed to give evidence at a trial ... , and [ provided that ] the document is in the possession of that person or the person for whose benefit the secrecy obligation has been prescribed . A document may nevertheless be seized if , under section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of the Pre - trial LAW , a person [ referred to in DATE , Article CARDINAL , of the Code of Judicial Procedure ] would have been entitled or obliged to give evidence in the pre - trial investigation about the matter contained in the document . "
CARDINAL . ORG LAW , LAW CARDINAL , of the LAW reads :

" At the request of a person whom the case concerned , the court shall decide whether the seizure shall remain in force . A request which has been submitted to the court before its examination of the charges shall be considered within DATE from its reception by the court . The examination of such a request is , in as far as appropriate , governed by the provisions in chapter CARDINAL , sections DATE , on the examination of requests for detention on remand . The court shall reserve those with an interest in the matter an opportunity to be heard , but the absence of anyone shall not preclude a decision on the issue . "

CARDINAL . ORG Under ORG DATE ( laki yleisten asiakirjain julkisuudesta , lag om allmänna handlingars offentlighet CARDINAL ) , official documents are in principle public ( section CARDINAL ) . They include not only documents drawn up and issued by an authority but also documents submitted to an authority and which are in its possession ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) . A pre - trial investigation record , however , shall not be public until the matter has been brought before a court or the police investigation has been closed without charges being brought ( section CARDINAL ) .

Everyone has access to official public documents ( section CARDINAL , as amended by Act no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . However , medical reports are accessible to the public only with the consent of the person to whom they relate ( section CARDINAL ) . In the absence of such consent , a party to criminal proceedings shall nevertheless have access to such documents if they are capable of affecting the outcome of the case ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) , as amended by Act no . CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . GPE evidence obtained during a pre - trial investigation shall be kept in a record of investigation , if this is considered necessary for the further consideration of the case . The record shall include all documents assumed to be of importance and indicate , inter alia , whether other documentary evidence has been obtained but omitted from the record ( section CARDINAL of the Pre - trial LAW ) .

CARDINAL . ORG If all or part of an oral hearing has been held in camera or if , during such a hearing , any confidential document or information has been submitted , the court may decide that all or part of the case material be kept confidential for DATE . The operative part of the judgment and the legal provisions relied on shall always be made public ( section CARDINAL of ORG laki oikeudenkäynnin julkisuudesta , lag om offentlighet vid rättegång CARDINAL ) ) .
No separate appeal against a decision concerning the publicity of proceedings is allowed ( LAW ) . The decision must thus be challenged in an ordinary appeal lodged by a party to the proceedings .

CARDINAL . ORG Under the DATE LAW ( rikoslaki , strafflag CARDINAL ) , the disclosure of confidential information by a civil servant or a public employee is a criminal offence ( chapter DATE , which has been amended subsequently ) .

CARDINAL . ORG Under LAW ( Suomen hallitusmuoto , NORP för GPE CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) , anyone whose rights have been infringed and who has suffered damage as a result of an illegal act , or by the negligence , of a civil servant , is entitled to prosecute the civil servant , or to demand that he or she be prosecuted , and to claim damages ( Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ) . Under LAW DATE ( vahingonkorvauslaki , skadeståndslag CARDINAL ) proceedings may also be brought against the ORG for actions taken by civil servants ( chapters CARDINAL and DATE ) .

CARDINAL . ORG A person involved in a pre - trial investigation may be prohibited , on pain of a fine or a maximum of CARDINAL months’ imprisonment , from revealing information concerning third parties which was not previously known to him or her and which relates to the investigation . Such a prohibition may be imposed if the disclosure of such information in the course of the investigation is liable to jeopardise the investigation or to cause harm or be prejudicial to a party to the investigation or to any third party . Heavier sentences may be imposed if the disclosure constitutes a separate offence ( section CARDINAL of the Pre - trial LAW ) .

CARDINAL . ORG Under ORG DATE , neither parties nor their representatives are allowed to disclose confidential material which has been made available to them in their capacity as parties to persons not involved in the proceedings ( section CARDINALa ) . Disclosure in breach of this rule is punishable by a fine ( section CARDINAL ) .
